question.answer: Abstract data type with a collection of objects.
Abstract data type with an ordered sequence of values.
Abstract data type with an unordered sequence of values without repeated values.
A set that allows repeated values or duplicates.
Abstract data type with a collection of keys and associated values.
Abstract data type with vertices and edges.
Abstract data type with push and pop in last-in-first-out (LIFO) order.
Abstract data type with push and pop in first-in-first-out (FIFO) order.
Abstract data type that allows fast min (or max) retrieval. Usually implemented with a heap.
A queue allowing addition or removal from either end.
A priority queue allowing removal of both the min and max.

subsection.title: Trees

question.answer: Allows traversal of a tree of nodes.
A tree whose child nodes are in sorted order, allowing binary search of the whole tree.

question.text: Self-Balancing Binary Search Tree (Balanced Binary Search Tree)
question.answer: A binary search tree that keeps its height small.
A binary search tree with the smallest possible search time for certain queries.
A tree whose nodes have no more than 2 children.
A tree in which a node of order k has children who are roots of trees of order k, k-1, ... 0. So each child's tree is deeper than its sibling child's tree. Permits easy merging of trees.
A self-balancing tree in which each node can have multiple keys, separating multiple child nodes.
B-Tree of order 3.
B-Tree of order 4.
A self-balancing binary search tree that, after an insert or deletion, rotates the lowest node whose child nodes' heights differ by more than 1..

A self-balancing binary search tree that, after an insert or deletion, rotates the lowest nodes that do not satisfy the coloring constraints: Root is black. All leaves are black. All children of red nodes are black. All paths to leaves contains the same number of black nodes.
A heap-ordered tree whose in-order traversal recreates the original sequence.
Stores all k prefixes of n strings.
A trie that uses less space by having 3 BST-like branches at each node.

question.text: Radix Tree (Radix Trie, Compact Prefix Tree, Patricia Trie)
question.answer: Space-optimized trie.
Stores all k suffixes of n strings, allowing searches for all substrings.
Associative array allowing fast O(lg lg N) successor/predecessor, and O(1) max/min, on keys of limited range N. by using a hierarchy of of clusters, each with a min and max.
Stores prefix sums (running totals). Has O(n log(n)) construction time, O(log(n)) update time, and O(log(n)) retrieval time.
Stores intervals or segments and allows efficient searching for intervals that contain a certain point, or to query for a range sum or range minium.
Stores intervals or segments and allows efficient searching for intervals that overlap a certain interval.

Allows efficient O((log n)^d + k) time searching for points that are within a certain interval. (Orthogonal Range Search). Particularly for searching in multiple dimensions. Using O(n(log n)^d-1) space.

subsection.question: Order Statistic Tree https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_statistic_tree Supports rank() and select() in O(log n) time..
Finger Search Tree https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finger_search_tree Allows fast search to nearby keys, in O(log(rank(x) - rank(y))) time..

question.answer: A tree-based structure whose parent nodes are less (for a min heap) or greater (for a max heap) than their children, allowing fast min (or max) retrieval.
A heap implemented with a binary tree, which is complete (all levels are filled, apart from leaves, which are filled from left to right.)
A mergeable heap, implemented as a collection of binomial trees.
A heap implemented as a collection of heaps, allowing fast decrease-key, delete, and merge.
A self-balancing binary search tree that is also a min (or max) heap in terms of a random weight for each node, resulting in a random binary search tree that is likely to be balanced.
Tests membership, with possibility of false positives.
Groups items into subsets.
Lists nodes and their incident (often only outgoing) edges.
For any 2 nodes, provides the edge, if any, that connects them.
Allows forward traversal of the items in the list.
Allows forward and backward traversal of the items in the list.
Maps keys to values using a hash function.
A linked hierarchy of ordered elements, starting with the sparsest subsequence.
Binary Search Tree that optimizes itself for recently accessed elements.
Allows proximity search in k-dimensional data by partitioning the space.

subsection.title: Trees

question.answer: Nodes with a data field and pointers to child nodes.
Array or tree structure.

question.text: Self-Balancing Binary Search Tree (Balanced Binary Search Tree)
question.answer: Perform local rotation transformations after changes.
Construct initially and prevent modification, using dynamic programming. Or balance optimally (theoretically) after each modification.
Nodes with a data field and pointers to only 2 child nodes.
A tree in which a node of order k has children who are roots of trees of order k, k-1, ... 0. Construct by merging trees of same order, by adding the second tree as a child of the first tree's root.
Nodes with multiple keys separating multiple child nodes. Nodes with d keys have d+1 child nodes.
B-Tree of order 3. Nodes with 1 or 2 keys separating 2 or 3 child nodes, respectively.
B-Tree of order 4. Nodes with 1, 2, or 3 keys separating 2, 3 or 4 child nodes, respectively.
After an insert or deletion, rotates the lowest node whose child nodes' heights differ by more than 1.

After an insert or deletion, rotates the lowest nodes that do not satisfy the coloring constraints: Root is black. All leaves are black. All children of red nodes are black. All paths to leaves contains the same number of black nodes.
Construct the tree in (amortized) O(n) time by adding each node to the previous node, walking up the tree and splitting an edge if necessary, making children into left nodes.
Keys are defined by their position in the tree, with each edge being the next character (or bit) of the key, and with values associated with leaf nodes.
Keys are defined by their position in the tree, with each node having a character and three links to nodes for the subsequent character - either a lesser, greater, or equal character.

question.text: Radix Tree (Radix Trie, Compact Prefix Tree)
question.answer: Keys are defined by their position in the tree, with each edge being the next chunk of the key, and with values associated with leaf nodes.
Compressed Trie, with text suffixes as keys and text positions as values.
A hierarchy of of clusters that summarize less sparse clusters, each with a min and max.
Array in which the index of child, parent, and next nodes are calculated using bitwise operations. The prefix sum is the sum of the node and its parent nodes.
Store the node values as an array, as in a binary heap, using the start of the range as the node's key. Each node summarizes its child nodes.

A ternary tree, in which each node has a center point and links to nodes whose intervals are completely before or completely after the interval, as well as lists of overlapping intervals, in order of their start, and in order of their end. Or alternatively, a (balanced) binary tree with intervals in each node, using the interval's start as the key. Each node is augmented with the maximum interval end for itself and its children.

A complete balanced binary tree with points in the nodes. Examine right parents of the start and left parents of the end, listing all the parent nodes, and their subtrees, to the right of the start and to the left of the end. Each subtree has a range tree of the points by another dimension.

subsection.question: Order Statistic Tree https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_statistic_tree Augment a (balanced) binary search tree, maintaining the size of each node's subtree in the node..

Finger Search Tree https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finger_search_tree A level-linked 2-3 tree in which each node has links to next and previous nodes on the same level, and each node maintains the min and max in its subtree..

question.answer: A bit array and a set of hash functions to map keys to positions.
A tree-based data struture, for instance in an array. Each position's value is the position of its parent.
A list of each node and its edges.
A 2-dimensional array of node connections.
Nodes with a data field and a pointer to the next node.
Nodes with a data field and both a pointer to the next node and a pointer to the previous node.

A hash function that maps keys to buckets in an array, resolving collisions either by Separate Chaining (linked list of items in each bucket) or Open Addressing (items stored in next available bucket).
A linked hierarchy of ordered elements, starting with the sparsest subsequence.
A binary search tree. After insertion, deletion, or searching, the node is rotated to become the root.

A binary tree. Each node defines a hyperplane and its left and right children are either side of that hyperplane. Typically the hyperplane will be chosen by cycling through the axes as we move down the tree. Each node is the median of the points in its subtree.
Usually implemented with an array. The K children of position i are from Ki+1 to Ki+K.
Usually implemented with an array. The children of position i are at 2i+1 and 2i+2.
Store the roots of the binomial trees in an ordered list. Find minimum by finding the minimum root. Merge trees by making the larger root a child of the smaller root.

A collection of heap-ordered trees, which are like binomial trees, but do not need to be restructured upon node removal. Each node has a doubly-linked list of its children. The roots of the trees are in a circular doubly-linked list. Nodes are marked when restructuring is necessary but that cleanup operations are deferred.
A cartesian tree that satisfies the heap property for random weights. Insert as per node value order and then rotate to maintain heap property for the random weight.
List the nodes first from the root down the left to the leaf, then back up from left to right.
Lists the items in sorted order.
List the nodes from the bottom of each path up to the root, listing shared nodes last, from left to right.
Find the node by comparing its key.
Find the node with the next key in order.
Find the node with the previous key in order.
Add a node with the specified key.
Remove a node with the specified key.
Use the current node, recurse into left tree, recurse into right tree.
Put root on stack. while(stack not empty), take from stack, use current node, put right then left on stack.
Recurse into left tree, use the current node, recurse into right tree.
While(stack not empty), while(current is null), travel leftwards, adding nodes to the stack. Pop and use the left-most node. Put the right node on the stack and set it as current.
Recurse into left tree, recurse into right tree, use the current node.
Use 2 stacks. Put root on stack1. while(stack1 not empty), take from stack1, put on stack2, put left and right on stack1. while(stack2 not empty), take from stack and use.
Add root to a queue. While(queue not empty), pop a node from the queue, use it, add left to the queue, add right to the queue.
Compare with root's key and then search in the left or right subtree, comparing each node's key and then going left or right.
Find left-most child of right child. Or if there is no right child, find the nearest ancestor that is an ancestor's left child.
Find right-most child of left child. Or if there is no left child, find the nearest ancestor that is an ancestor's right child.
Search for the node's key until we find a null child. Put the node in that position.

If there are 2 child nodes: Find the successor. If there is no successor then there is no right child, so replace the node with the left child. If there is a successor, replace the node with the successor, making the node's left child be the successor's left node, making the sucessor's original parent be the successor's right child and making the successor's original right child be the successor's original parent's left child.
The node's right child becomes its parent, with the node as the left child. The right child's left child becomes the node's right child.
The node's left child becomes its parent, with the node as the right child. The left child's right child becomes the node's left child.
Duplicate the tree. Generate a prefix representation of an expression tree.
List the nodes in order.
Delete the entire tree, by deleting children before parents. Generate a postfix representation of an expression tree.
Each bucket is independent, and has a list of entries with the same index.
All entry records are stored in the bucket array itself. Lookups may examine a series of buckets.
A key will be relocated if its probe count is higher than for the new key.
2 hash functions provide 2 potential positions for a key. The key is placed where there would be fewer collisions.
Advantages: Simple implementation. Avoids rehashing. Disadvantage: Pointer chasing causes cache misses. Extra space.
Advantage: Data locality gives good cache performance. Disdvantage: Requires reallocation and rehashing.
Advantage: Reduces worst case search times.
The buckets are examined, starting with the hashed-to slot and proceeding in some probe sequence, until an unoccupied slot is found.
Hybrid of separate chaining and open addressing, chaining from filled buckets to unused buckets.

The key is re-hashed with other hash functions to find an empty bucket. (All hashes may be tried during lookup.) If all collide, the existing key is re-hashed, possibly causing further re-hashing. If this eventually fails, the table is resized.
The key is always in the neighborhood of the original bucket. If necessary, existing items are moved, though without moving them outside of their neighbourhoods.
Fast insertion and fast search.
No clustering effects; in fact, the table can be efficiently filled to a high density.
Constant lookup time in the worst case, and constant amortized time for insertions and deletions.
Works well even when the load factor grows beyond 0.9. Allows use of simple hash function.
The interval between probes is fixed — often at 1.
The interval between probes increases linearly (the indices are described by a quadratic function).
The interval between probes is computed by another hash function.
Advantage: best cache performance. Disadvantage: worst clustering.
Advantage: good cache performance and minimal clustering.
Advantage: no clustering. Disadvantage: worst cache performance.
